reviews.text:
One Egypt’s nicest museums. It would get a five star rating but the ticket salesmen would not give me the proper change for the longest time.

Well organized and nice artifacts on display.
Really great museum! A lot of info and easy to walk through. Not a must do... But if you have time you should go!

This was the most unexpected find in Egypt. It's actually a very high quality museum that tells the whole history of the Nubian area from prehistoric humans through the UNESCO project to save Egyptian monuments from the flooding caused by the Aswan High Dam in the mid 1900s. The museum is small and has limited artifacts, but the story it tells is very complete. 

I am sad to say that I wish the Egyptian Museum in Cairo was even a quarter put together as the Nubian Museum. Very well done and worth the afternoon to visit.

Nice museum. Some of the displays were a bit hard to read because of the low light. The Nubian homes with mannequins in folk costume were very interesting. Also, the gardens were pretty. Be sure to bring exact change, as several people before us were turned away for lack of change. Great to have an opportunity to learn more about this culture.

This is the best museum experience we have had in Egypt. The building is modern, attractive and cool inside.  The exhibits are well laid out, well lit and have good explanations.  There are also good summaries of the general history of Nubia throughout the ages.

You really can you here and enjoy the place without a guide.

We didn’t get any hassle at all as well, which is a first.
The historic Fatimid cemetery contains several hundred mudbrick Islamic tombs, built between the 8th and 12th centuries.
Not fenced, stumbled upon it while walking from the cathedral to unfinished obelisk. It deserves to be at least signposted. Not touristy at all.
♥♥♥ I want to visit it.
My father is there :(
Not for vist
😁😁😁❤️❤️❤️😍Amazing hustle and bustle of the streets.. Spices crafts.. Camels, tea in the NUBIAN house... Bright and beautiful walls street art.. Very interesting.. What a great experience.

We really enjoyed our brief visit here.  As you exit your boat, there's a market on the main street with a number of different shops, places to eat, and accommodation. What impressed me the most, was the artwork and pastel colors on most of the buildings.  It's no more than a 15-minute boat ride from Aswan city center.
Nice, vintage And Native. Natural spices available and hand made cloths available. Natives try to be smart with cost price and insects population a bit high. But Nice place to visit.

This place is worth a visit,  the Nubian tribe has great contributions to the Egypt history. You to go by a boat and they take you to a Nubian house,  which is a model of how they lived,  they serve you with tea,  Brad,  there is also crocodile which they believe you be god,  once the crocodile becomes big they let go in Nile River.  The huts are built with mud to keep in coming in dessert.  The government takes care of them with various benefits.  You get to see young children riding on the camel very fast,  there are old cars.  Also many handicrafts and shops.
Amazing place to dive into authentic Nubian way of life. Dresses, food, houses, alive crocodiles just at arm's length and what not. Amazing Nile Riverside views and old Aswan dam on the horizon
It's a beautiful island, with special people! they are so nice to Western people!! It was a great time there!
Amaizing place 😍
Loved the place there
Amazing place and nice memories

reviews.author_name: I Comment On A Lot of Videos
reviews.text: GREAT STUFF MON'
Cool monument atop a giant sand dune. It is worth checking out.

Kubbet El Hawa it's part of the Tomb of the nobles in Aswan, no matter how much you climb to see the tombs the view it's fascinated.  I suggest do not climb to top it's dangerous and don't risk your life..
The view feom the top is breathtaking, but its hard to climp
The view is great but it is a long hike
What you can view the whole Aswan from
Still in amazingly good shape for being built in 400 AD. Peaceful place to go...gorgeous views of desert.

Interesting example of a Coptic Christian Church in  Egypt that has also been used by Egyptian and Arab religions. The original church is a Balisica type (orthodox Christan), but a partial update has Arabic script decorations. 100 monks lived here at one point, with up to 300 visitors accommodated.

Monastery of St Simeon
Monastery in Aswan
The fortress-like 7th-century Monastery of St Simeon was first dedicated to the local saint Anba Hedra, who renounced the world on his wedding day. It was rebuilt in the 10th century and dedicated to St Simeon. From here the monks travelled into Nubia, in the hope of converting the Nubians to Christianity. To get there, take a private boat across the Nile then walk up the (mostly paved) desert track, or hire a camel to take you up.
Tickets & tours
Surrounded by desert sands, the monastery was built on two levels – the lower level of stone and the upper level of mud brick – surrounded by 10m-high walls. At its height, the monastery may have housed as many as 1000 monks, but it was partially destroyed by the troops of Saladin (Salah Ad Din) in 1173. The basilica has traces of frescoes. The cells still have their mastaba (bench) beds. The last room on the right includes graffiti from Muslim pilgrims who stayed here en route to Mecca.
An alternative way to get here is to take the ferry to the Tombs of the Nobles and ride a camel or donkey from there. Remember to bring water
Boat trip over is great. Take bins for bird watching. 🐫 trip of 10 mins to monastery. Needs a guide to bring it to life. Don't expect the same wow factor as the ancient Egyptian temples.
Unique Nubian Coptic architecture, well preserved eve it's more than 15 centuries old, beautiful vaults and amazing stories... Must visit

This site is amazing!!!! I could have spent a day here. The boat ride (yes, it is on an island) was nice. The boats definitely are locally maintained, but they worked well. And the view they offered of the site, both on arriving and departing was excellent. 

The ruins are excellent and exciting. Hard to describe as they were so...well, amazing. Each structure and area was a new experience. 

The site is large, but also easily walkable. Bring water and sunscreen. And of course, tips for the toilet keepers. 

Best part was that the vendors stayed on the dock.
Great restoration by UNESCO to preserve the amazing history of Pharaohs for generations to come.

A masterpiece.

This is so majestic and beautiful. The island and rocky shores are amazing. Best time is to go before sunsets to enjoy the colors and sunset views and take photos in this brilliant lighting condition where the temple will look legendary. It is a miracle how this temple was saved from the water behind the high dam and moved to this new location. Blessed are those who helped save this priceless and timeless masterpiece.

The boar trip is amazing with really great views. The Nile is crystal clear in this area. If you have time make sure to visit the nearby Heissa Island. I arrived late just to catch the temple but that island is said to be  very good.

One can get awestruck seeing the magical ancient creations,  Egypt particularly is so rich in ancient history and they have retained the ruins in the best form,  getting to this island is little heavy on the pocket, say about a 1000 EGP but you can get your negotiation skills work for you,  try going early morning or evening as sun hits you hard in the afternoon and God bless you if it's crowded hence do plan accordingly

Temple of Philae was originally located on the island of Philae
Even before Aswan dam was constructed, after construction of Aswan Low dam Temple of Philae used to be flooded during most part of the year. 
So, like many monuments which were relocated die to building of Aswan dam, Temple of Philae was also relocated on the island of Agilika.
Temple has held very important place as centre for the worship of Goddess Isis through the history. It was revered and worshipped by Egyptian, Romans as well as Greek. Roman influence is clearly indicated by the typical Roman pillars in Temple construction.
Temple consists of two very impressive gates, a courtyard, Vestibule, sanctuary and Trojan kiosk.
First gate is massive and impressive. It is18 meters high. Two giant granite lion statues are placed on either side of the entrance gate. Walls of the gates have hieroglyphics depicting King preforming various functions.
After the first gate we enter the main courtyard. On both sides they're are large vestibule with huge pillars. The walls as well as the pillars have hieroglyphics reliefs showing various events and Kings and gods.
Second gate is also huge but slightly smaller in height at 12 meters. The walls of this gate also have reliefs.
After this you enter the inner Temple through a eight pillared vestibule. Etching of the Cross in this area indicates that some time this temple was transformed in Christian place of worship. Reliefs in the visible are left unfinished and in quite bad shape.
After passing few side rooms we finally reach the sanctuary. It is liot by two windows. Idol of the goddess would have been installed on the base of granite slab.
Trajans Kiosk.
This Temple is attributed to Emperor Trajan. It is beautiful but relatively small structure, 15 X20 meter kiosk and 15.85 meters high. Like other structures this is also roofless.

Breathtaking temples. Place is crowded when you arrive really early morning with all the tourist bus. If you can travel independently I would recommend getting there around 9am and you will enjoy the place completely to yourself as the tourist bus all leave around this time.

Must see place no matter what. Fantastic temple of King Ramses II and Queen Nefertari. Relocated to higher ground during construction of the Aswan dam. Great pictures. Have to pay for photography, but well worth it. Temples are lit. There is also a golf cart one can pay for to get up the steep inclines. Again, a great site to visit.

This historic and cultural masterpiece is mesmerising. Dating back to Ramses the great and his lover Nefertiti's temple it is truly jaw dropping. The engineering feat undertaken by UNESCO to move this temple complex without destroying it and maintaining the historic, cultural and solar alignment is nothing short of a miracle. Definitely worth the early riser, convoy and getting there as early as possible.

Nice to visit but it's a long way from big cities like Aswan. 
There isn't much else to do there except for some shops you can find anywhere in Egypt.

Deepest temple ever visited, lots of room inside. Impressive.   Must visit when in Aswan.  Every accommodation will book this for you for next day 4 am depending 1pm return. Cost L£ 200 - 300 for return ride plus L£ 215 for entrance tickets.  Bus will stop for 10 min each way

The Nubian special dish was good. The chicken kabob was soso. At the end they gave me a check for the drinks and then summed it up to 30% more than the actual charge. They corrected it but still... be aware

Ordered grilled chicken and roasted beef and when we paid the guy said “rice is extra 15 pounds” 

Really lol? Were you going to charge for the two slices of cucumbers and salt and pepper as well? 

Just tell them “No, you did not say it was extra” and you they will say “ok rice is free this time”

The food was OK.
Great food and atmosphere, awesome service. Relaxing
The food quality is so so. You have to check your bill when you pay it carefully. They try to add around 20% more.
It has nice view and reasonable prices
You will love this restaurant for sea foods. I ate crabs and shrimps here. Check out these photos to see the prices. The place is not far from Aswan train station.
The real meaning of hospitality,  the most professional restaurant of seafood in Aswan

Sea food  restaurant with average food  quality  and below average atmosphere and decor  ، staff  is not so friendly  they just doing their job .  In general it is average to below avarage restsurant but with very reasonable prices

A specialty sea food 
Very tasty, and logic prices
Wonderful restaurant !!!......one of the best....

Amazing experience.. The architecture is awesome.. the view is outstanding.. The service is perfect and the people there are very friendly.. It was my sister's birthday and they celebrated in a very decent way.. Special thanks to the waiters Hussein Nagy and Essam

The hotel is very luxurious and the view is amazing. A must see hotel that carries historic design and great amenities. Extremely good quality food for a reasonable price. Very friendly workers as well. Would definitely recommend
Could have been 5 stars. But the service really lets this glorious place down. Accor please lay some emphsis on service standards

This place is really amazing. It is a piece of art that reflects the historical nature of the place along with the French style. It is really mesmerizing to have you tea in the terrace watching sunset beyond the west bank. Their signature restaurant, 1902 is a must to experience place. Staff helpfulness and friendliness completes this beautiful portrait.

The first good thing about this hotel that strikes one is the view. Guests in rooms in the old building looking out over the Nile toward Elephantine Island and the spectacular desert beyond will understand why so many luminaries ranging from Antoine de Saint-Exupéry to Churchill via many heads of state and great Hollywood stars came to relax for a month or so at this excellent hotel. It is also the only hotel in Aswan that commands this particularly wonderful view. While it possessed an air of 'shabby-chic' before, the 'shabby' element is now completely banished with a very sympathetic restoration that retains the unique 'genius loci' that I enjoyed so much on my visit of 28 and 40 years ago. Faultless service from charming staff. Treat yourself and stay there, even if it is only once. So many of the world's great hotels have been 'homogenised' by chains and their particular charm and special qualities lost: the new owners have brought the place into the 21st century without spoiling its character in any way. There is a new block, the  'New Cataract' built in the gardens next door but, for my money, the original building, 'The Palace' or 'Old Cataract', is the only place to stay.
It's really awesome.
Best place to see Aswan
Beautiful View of Aswan City and Mesmerizing Sunset
Marvellous view
Fantastic
